captions.text: We stumbled upon a restaurant that specializes in shabu shabu
it's one of those dishes you've got to try in Japan
We went for a 'tabehodai' which is basically an all-you-can-it type of deal
As a starter we got fugu karage, deep-fried fugu fish.
We got the meat as well, just look at those yummy looking slices
We've also got many different veggies here
we'll be putting all those things in this pot
and we can order as many of them as we feel like.
The dashi stock is getting ready, its main ingredient is the kombu seaweed
that's the floating stuff.
As we splashed out on the VIP sized feast
we got some extra pork on the house to go with it.
Shabu shabu and nabe - its slightly different version
where you let the ingredients cook a little bit longer
but that's a story for another time
- are especially popular in Japan during winter.
It's the best thing - sitting down with your friends,
around this massive cooking pot,
chatting, laughing and - yeah, just stuffing your faces.
We're going to add a little bit of this paste here,
it's daikon - Japanese white radish, mixed with spicy pepper
and then you mix it with the ponzu sauce, traditionally served with the shabu shabu
ponzu itself is a vinegar and soy sauce mixture.
That's a very complex mathematical formula I just came up with.
Apart from ponzu, you also get the sesame sauce
That smell's insane.
And this one here... a bit like dashi, basic fish stock.
The veggies are boiling already, so we can start taking them out
one by one.
We then dip them in those amazing sauces...
and they're good to go.
All of the ingredients for the dish are here on the table,
you do it all by yourself, there's no mystery ingredient,
everything you'll need is laid out in front of you.
Now it's time for tonight's main feature, this beautiful Japanese beef
while it's not kobe beef, it still comes from the wagyu cattle - very high quality.
You dip it in the shabu shabu, and - actually, this is how the name 'shabu shabu' originated
from the sound you make when you stirr it, when you do the "shabu, shabu, shabu"
which is like going "mixy, mixy, mixy", I guess
And after literally 10 seconds our slice is nice and ready
let's add a little bit of this dipping sauce
Unbelievable.
As we are in good company of civilized young people, the chopsticks are not a problem
Right, let's try some of that complimentary pork they gave us.
We stir it just like we did with beef, it's the same motion.
A tad bit longer...
Okay, looks like it's ready.
We've got a seperate, different dipping sauce for the pork here, Krzysiek analyzed it already
I mean, really...
I have never tried pork so soft, so tender in my life. It's like velvet.
Of course, we had to order decent sake to go with it,
you wouldn't have some low-brow, plebeian beer to go with such food.
You want something proper.
So, our sake - it's been served in a very interesting, traditonal manner.
The glass has been put inside of a square, wooden... I guess you can call it a box
Now, the cool thing is, they overpour the sake until both glass and the box are full.
This nice custom comes from the restaurant staff striving to provide best possible service to their patrons
and overpouring the alcohol, letting it spill everywhere.
According to etiquette, you're not supposed to pour the sake back into the glass, but drink it straight from the box.
We're going to add a little bit of negi to the pork dipping sauce,
and negi is... I'm not sure what it is, really. Some sort of leek?
I think it's leek.
We also have this paste called yuzukosho
Yuzu is a kind of fruit, Polish name is 'yuzu' as well.
Dang that's goona be good with that yazu-whatever
I literally have tears in my eyes, this is so unbelievably good
Seriously, though, I'm about to cry.
We need to skim off that gooey scum that started froming here,
same happens when you cook chicken soup.
It's perfectly normal. Do not panic.
This honestly is one of the best meals I've had in my life.
Yeah, I've got my personal top 3,
It's tuna sashimi, I had it in Korea
then there is...
this massive shrimp I had in Portugal, in Lisbon
...and the meal I've had in Hotel Francuski in Kraków, it was Polish cuisine.
Now it looks like I'm going to have to expand it into a top 4,
you now, the top four best f**king meals in my life.
And the all-you-can-eat menu is a reasonable thing as well
...because the cuts they give you are like, f**k me...
...and you can eat it till you drop.
It's simply...

- Especially for us...
- Especially for us, Polish fatties
It's unbelievable. What you mentioned before - and I've got to agree
it's in the top 5 things I have eaten, easily
and if we're talking about the meat itself - well,
it was probably the best meat I've had in my life.
To be completely honest - it was pricey.
Well, the place is decent - not over the top fancy, but fancy enough,
we paid 6,000 yen each, so about 60 dollars, for having the pleasure of eating as much as we can for 2 hours.
As much meat as we want I mean - we couldn't care less about the veggies
While a single tray of this meat costs 4,000 yen
so they're trying to make it really obvious the all-you-can-eat menu makes bigger sense.
And eat till you reach the higher planes of consciousness.
I mean, look how huge this is.
It's not like I don't know how to behave myself
it'd actually be considered rude if I cut it all up.
You can dip it, yes, or try and fold it with your chopsticks
so it's easier to handle, but apart from that
you just have to eat a handful of meat in one bite.
This beef, guys. You could eat it inch after inch,
- A fraction of an inch is more like it...
That's right. And you could still enjoy it.
Well, here you grab those huge portions and stuff yourself with them.
And you can have as much as you like. I don't even...
To put it into a wider perspective - people in Japane care greatly about their food
the way it looks, the way it tastes.
I've never had an experience going to a restaurant here, even the lousiest kind
and being served something off-putting, something that was bad quality or simply unappetizing.
This dish is all about the outstanding ingredients,
not about a complex, sophisticated recipe.
An obligatory finale to every standard shabu shabu type meal
is eating the stock, that's been slowly brewing all throughout the evening
You don't have to eat the whole thing, it's more of a gesture.
We can add some spices as well
hot chilli, some pepper...
I'll leave the salt out, we're in Japan.
This soup is something we ourselves brought to existence, during our two hours of munching.
It's good f**cking beef stock, that's what it is.
At the very end there's mochi,
a kind of rice paste, molded into this shape
It's definitely an experience
finishing your meal with this soup,
a soup that happened kind of 'by the way'
while we were preparing the meat.
So that was traditional Japanese shabu shabu,
a meal that made Yuen cry tears of joy tonight.
For me it was one of the best meals ever as well
and while I didn't cry this time - I did cry with all the better ones -
- well, it was still something to die for.
If you're ever in Japan - you know what to do.
watch more videos on  youtube.com/wybuchajacebeczki

title: Najpyszniejsze mięso świata - Shabu Shabu [Tokio, Japonia] // Shabu shabu = heaven [Eng subs]
